document.text:
From: White Collar Law360 <news@law360.com> 
To:
Subject: Ex-SFO Boss Says Collusion Claims Were Drunken Boasts' 
Date: Wed, 14 Jul 2021 07:34:39 +0000 
R 
WHITE COLLAR 
Wednesday, July 14, 2021 `'Follow Law360 
TOP NEWS 
Ex-SFO Boss Says Collusion Claims Were 'Drunken Boasts' 
A former SFO chief defended his decision not to investigate "absurd" 
accusations that the agency fed insider information to help a Dechert attorney 
win work on high-profile fraud cases, testifying Tuesday that these were 
"probably the boasts of a man in drink." 
Read full 
article 
» 
Exclusive 
NFL Concussion Deal Masters Say Atty Fabricated Evidence 
A Florida attorney accused of swindling NFL players out of their life savings 
also "engaged in a wide-ranging, long-standing, and brazen pattern and 
practice of manufacturing evidence" for concussion settlement payout claims, 
the settlement's special masters found in a recent decision to disqualify the 
lawyer and his former firm. 
Motion attached I Read full article » 
Manafort Banker Convicted Of Bribery 
Former Federal Savings Bank CEO Stephen Calk on Tuesday was convicted 
of financial institution bribery and conspiracy, over allegations that the banker 
sought to exchange $16 million in loans to Paul Manafort for his help in getting 
a job in the administration of former President Donald Trump. 
Read full 
article » 
FCC Tightens Rules To Eradicate Contraband Phones In Jails 
To crack down on extortion plots perpetrated from inside prisons and jails, the 
Federal Communications Commission is requiring mobile providers to shut 
down contraband cellphones in correctional facilities. 
Order attached I Read full article 
O8A 
Ex-Grassley Atty Says Trust Is Key To Whistleblower Venture 
Jason Foster, ex-chief investigative counsel to former Senate Judiciary 
Committee Chairman Chuck Grassley, R-lowa, speaks to Law360 about the 
mission behind his new nonprofit Empower Oversight, an organization that will 
assist whistleblowers in government and corporate America. 
Read full article 
Feds Want 18 Mos. For Man Who Threatened Flynn Judge 
Federal prosecutors have recommended 18 months in prison for a man who 
threatened to assault and murder the D.C. federal judge overseeing the 
politically charged criminal case of ex-Trump national security adviser Michael 
Flynn. 
2 documents attached I Read full article »

COMPLIANCE 
Rail Execs Plead Guilty In Worker Safety Case After Explosion 
The owners of a rail car cleaning service that employed two workers killed in a 
2015 explosion pled guilty Monday to charges related to the deaths, which 
prosecutors said came after a history of safety violations. 
Read full 
article 
» 
SECURITIES 
7th Circ. Again Upholds First Market Spoofing Conviction 
The Seventh Circuit upheld the conviction and sentence for the first trader ever 
found guilty of spoofing the commodities market for a second time Monday, 
rejecting his argument that conflicted counsel and newly acquired evidence 
were enough to receive a new trial. 
Opinion attached [  Read full 
article 
» 
SEC Seeks $6.4M From Duo In Cannabis Investment Scheme 
The U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission wants a self-styled movie 
producer and his business partner to pay nearly $6.4 million for allegedly 
defrauding investors out of $4.85 million in a would-be recreational cannabis 
business. 
Motion attached I Read full article » 
INSURANCE 
Ga. Insurance Commissioner Embezzled $2M, Jury Told 
Georgia's suspended insurance commissioner Jim C. Beck duped friends and 
family into helping him embezzle more than $2 million from the state-regulated 
insurance association he used to run, a federal jury heard during trial openings 
Tuesday. 
Indictment attached j  Read full 
article » 
Insurer Hits Banks With Suit Over $19M Wire Fraud 
An insurer asked a federal judge in Texas to order banks including Bank of 
America and other institutions to freeze and return nearly $20 million it said it 
was tricked into wiring. 
Complaint attached I Read full article » 
TAX 
Feds Fight Architect's Bid To Split Tribal Bribery Case 
Federal prosecutors said Monday that tax charges against a former 
Massachusetts tribal chair should be tried at the same time as claims he 
accepted bribes from an architect in connection with a casino project. 
2 documents attached I Read full article » 
2nd Circ. Affirms $4.3M FBAR Penalty, Says Old Reg Invalid 
The U.S. government can collect a $4.3 million foreign bank account reporting 
penalty from a man's estate after a split Second Circuit said Tuesday that a 
1980s-era regulation capping the penalty was supplanted by a statutory 
amendment. 
Opinion 
attached I 
Read full article 
» 
PEOPLE 
Cooley Adds Experienced NY Prosecutor To Litigation Group 
A former New York federal prosecutor who led the prosecutions of many high-
profile figures, including former attorney Michael Cohen and financier Jeffrey

announced Tuesday. 
Read full 
article » 
EXPERT ANALYSIS 
Digging Into FCA Stats: In-House Litigation Budget Insights 
A deep dive into data about False Claims Act cases, beyond the U.S. 
Department of Justice's annual statistics, reveals trends that could affect in-
house counsel budgeting for FCA litigation and enable better assessment of 
what life as an FCA defendant may look like, says Ralph Mayrell at Robbins 
Russell. 
Read full 
article 
» 
Keys To Efficient And Accurate Doc Review For E-Discovery 
Attorneys involved in e-discovery can review information accurately and cost-
effectively by understanding the data in a document collection and identifying 
its key pitfalls, drafting comprehensive review guidelines, and preparing ahead, 
says John Wertelet at Eckert Seamans. 
Read full 
article 
» 
G. 
LEGAL INDUSTRY 
Law360 Pulse 
Duane Morris' McSwain To Trump: Pa. Election A 'Disgrace' 
Duane Morris partner William McSwain, a former Philadelphia federal 
prosecutor with his eyes on the Pennsylvania's governor's office, called the 
state's presidential election a "partisan disgrace" in a bid for Donald Trump's 
backing. 
Read full article » 
Davis Polk Will Try Out Attys Returning To Office Most Days 
Davis Polk & Wardwell LLP will require attorneys to report to the office at least 
seven out of every 10 business days starting in September, the firm confirmed 
to Law360 on Tuesday, making it the latest major law firm to announce plans 
for more of its lawyers to be back at the office in the fall. 
Read full 
article 
» 
Atty Moves Up The Coke Chain To GC For North America 
A longtime Coca-Cola attorney has been promoted to general counsel for 
North America, he said in a Linkedln post Monday, the latest change in the 
beverage giant's legal department this year. 
Read full 
article » 
Facebook Hires ACLU Atty For Civil Rights Team 
Facebook Inc. has hired an American Civil Liberties Union legislative attorney 
to serve as associate general counsel for its civil rights team. 
Read full 
article 
» 
Podcast 
Pro Say Movie Club: 'Legally Blonde' 
Twenty years ago today, sorority queen Elle Woods proved that law school was 
for more than just people who were "boring and ugly and serious" as she 
conquered Harvard Law in the iconic 2001 comedy "Legally Blonde." 
Read full 
article 
»
